name: Pythagorean trigonometric identity
explanation: The identity cos^2 A + sin^2 A = 1 relating squares of sine and cosine for any angle A.

name: Law of Sines (sine rule)
explanation: The relationship a/sin A = b/sin B = c/sin C between side lengths and opposite angles in a triangle.

name: Law of Cosines (cosine rule)
explanation: The formula a^2 = b^2 + c^2 − 2bc cos A relating the sides of a triangle to the cosine of one angle (generalisation of Pythagoras).

name: Sum and difference (compound-angle) identities for sine and cosine
explanation: Formulas for sin(A ± B) and cos(A ± B), e.g. sin(A+B)=sin A cos B + cos A sin B and analogous cosine formulas.

name: Tangent addition and subtraction formulas
explanation: Formulas for tan(A ± B) expressed in terms of tan A and tan B (e.g. (tan A + tan B)/(1 − tan A tan B)).

name: Double-angle identities
explanation: Identities for sin 2A, cos 2A and tan 2A, including alternate forms (e.g. cos 2A = cos^2 A − sin^2 A = 1 − 2 sin^2 A etc.).

name: Power-reduction / half-angle identities
explanation: Identities expressing sin^2 A and cos^2 A in terms of cos 2A (e.g. cos^2 A = 1/2(1 + cos 2A), sin^2 A = 1/2(1 − cos 2A)), and related half-angle forms.

name: Product-to-sum identities
explanation: Formulas converting products of sines and cosines into sums, e.g. 2 cos A cos B = cos(A+B)+cos(A−B), 2 sin A sin B = cos(A−B) − cos(A+B).

name: Sum-to-product identities
explanation: Formulas converting sums or differences of sines/cosines into products, e.g. cos A + cos B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) cos((A−B)/2), sin A − sin B = 2 cos((A+B)/2) sin((A−B)/2).

name: Derivation / dependency of identities
explanation: The procedural concept that some identities are derived from earlier ones and may be used to prove subsequent formulae (proof-order dependency).
strand: Mathematical proof and reasoning (applied to Trigonometry)
